Base:Descriptions.Base:Description: Approximately twelve feet by twelve feet, this stall provides a comfortable yet compact home for livestock. The pine walls enclosing the space are six feet in height and painted a deep shade of hunter green. A double-hung door in a contrasting warm cream hue occupies much of the southern wall, flanked on either side by hitching posts to which an animal can be better secured. In the northern wall is a small, single-pane window that lights the area during the daytime hours. A pair of troughs, one filled with cool, clean water and the other filled with oats, stands beneath the window. Hay is strewn about the dark red stone floor and piled high in the northwestern corner, both for idle munching and for soft bedding.

Approximately twelve feet by twelve feet, this stall provides a comfortable yet compact home for livestock. The pine walls enclosing the space are six feet in height and painted a deep shade of hunter green. A double-hung door in a contrasting warm cream hue occupies much of the southern wall, flanked on either side by hitching posts to which an animal can be better secured. In the northern wall is a small, single-pane window that lights the area during the daytime hours. A pair of troughs, one filled with cool, clean water and the other filled with oats, stands beneath the window. Hay is strewn about the dark red stone floor and piled high in the northwestern corner, both for idle munching and for soft bedding.

Approximately twelve feet by twelve feet, this stall provides a comfortable yet compact home for livestock. The pine walls enclosing the space are six feet in height and painted a deep shade of hunter green. A double-hung door in a contrasting warm cream hue occupies much of the southern wall, flanked on either side by hitching posts to which an animal can be better secured. In the northern wall is a small, single-pane window that lights the area during the daytime hours. A pair of troughs, one filled with cool, clean water and the other filled with oats, stands beneath the window. Hay is strewn about the dark red stone floor and piled high in the northwestern corner, both for idle munching and for soft bedding.
a double-hung stall door leading south
Crafted from pine and painted a deep shade of hunter green, the double-hung door leading to the south features upper and lower panels, which can be opened separately. $(parent-desc)
Hay has been piled high in the northwestern corner of the stall.

Six feet in height and twelve feet in width, the north wall of this stall butts up against the exterior wall of the building. It is crafted from planks of pine sanded smooth and painted a deep shade of hunter green. Aligned horizontally, the planks are affixed on either end to a matching support beam that extends up to the high ceiling above. Two additional planks in a contrasting cream color are fastened crossways to the surface to reinforce the half-height wall. A small, dusty window has been set into this surface just above the cross point of the cream-colored reinforcement beams.

Six feet in height and twelve feet in width, the north wall of this stall butts up against the exterior wall of the building. It is crafted from planks of pine sanded smooth and painted a deep shade of hunter green. Aligned horizontally, the planks are affixed on either end to a matching support beam that extends up to the high ceiling above. Two additional planks in a contrasting cream color are fastened crossways to the surface to reinforce the half-height wall. A small, dusty window has been set into this surface just above the cross point of the cream-colored reinforcement beams.

Six feet in height and twelve feet in width, the south wall of this stall is crafted from planks of pine sanded smooth and painted a deep shade of hunter green. Aligned horizontally, the planks are affixed on either end to a matching support beam that extends up to the high ceiling above. A double-hung door painted a warm cream hue occupies most of this half-height wall.

Six feet in height and twelve feet in width, the south wall of this stall is crafted from planks of pine sanded smooth and painted a deep shade of hunter green. Aligned horizontally, the planks are affixed on either end to a matching support beam that extends up to the high ceiling above. A double-hung door painted a warm cream hue occupies most of this half-height wall.
A small, single-pane window coated in a fine layer of dust is set in the northern wall, permitting the space some light during the daytime hours. Through the window and dust:
